intro: Hymenoxys parodii, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its showy, bright orange to yellow ray florets. The plant typically grows as an annual or biennial herb with hairy, branched stems and alternate leaves. Its flowers bloom in late summer to early fall, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Hymenoxys parodii is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is relatively easy to grow in well-drained soil.
